p: African horse sickness (AHS) is a viral disease of equids caused by the African horse sickness virus (AHSV), a RNA virus from the genus Orbivirus. The virus is principally transmitted by Culicoides spp. midges and is endemic in most of sub-Saharan Africa with all nine types occurring regularly, affecting domestic horses, donkeys and wild equids, such as zebra. Infections in domestic horses result in significant clinical disease, leading to a high mortality rate, ranging from 50% to 95%, in naive animals, whereas infections in zebra are asymptomatic [ 1].
